docs.title: Tadd Bindas
docs.text: Large-Scale hydrological modeler. Author of \(\delta\)MC, and lab member of the Multiscale Hydrologic Processes and Intelligence group at Penn State. Developer at Earth Resources Technologies working to improve flood predictions.

docs.title: Improving River Routing Using a Differentiable Muskingum-Cunge Model and Physics-Informed Machine Learning
docs.text:
Info

To view this paper's Github Code, see the Github URL at the top-right of the nav bar.

A novel differentiable modeling framework to perform routing and to learn a “parameterization scheme” (a systematic way of inferring parameters from more rudimentary information) for routing flows on the river network.

Below are the main points from the paper:

  • A novel differentiable routing model can learn effective river routing parameterization, recovering channel roughness in synthetic runs.
  • With short periods of real training data, we can improve streamflow in large rivers compared to models not considering routing.
  • For basins >2,000 km2, our framework outperformed deep learning models that assume homogeneity, despite bias in the runoff forcings.
@article{bindas2024improving,
  title={Improving River Routing Using a Differentiable Muskingum-Cunge Model and Physics-Informed Machine Learning},
  author={Bindas, Tadd and Tsai, Wen-Ping and Liu, Jiangtao and Rahmani, Farshid and Feng, Dapeng and Bian, Yuchen and Lawson, Kathryn and Shen, Chaopeng},
  journal={Water Resources Research},
  volume={60},
  number={1},
  pages={e2023WR035337},
  year={2024},
  publisher={Wiley Online Library}
}

docs.title: Differentiable modelling to unify machine learning and physical models for geosciences
docs.text:
A description of specific method of physics-informed machine learning. In this approach, we implement a physics equation using a differentiable coding platform, then use embedded NNs to estimate parameters. The embedded NNs are then tuned through the differentiable physics function, constraining the NNs with physics.

docs.title: Testing
docs.text: Well, I didn't think I would ever write my own blog. But, here we are

docs.title: Marquette
docs.text:
Marquette is a tool designed to format Hydrofabric data such that it can be used for \(\delta\)MC. Currently the following hydrofabric inputs are supported:

  • MERIT-BASINS

docs.title: Citation
docs.text:
Official citation coming soon. For now, use:

@misc{Bindas2024,
  author = {Bindas, T},
  title = {Marquette: A hydrofabric formatting tool},
  year = {2024},
  publisher = {GitHub},
  journal = {GitHub repository},
  howpublished = {\url{https://github.com/taddyb/marquette}},
}

docs.title: Welcome to MkDocs
docs.text: For full documentation visit mkdocs.org.

docs.title: Commands
docs.text:
• mkdocs new [dir-name] - Create a new project.
  • mkdocs serve - Start the live-reloading docs server.
  • mkdocs build - Build the documentation site.
  • mkdocs -h - Print help message and exit.

docs.title: Project layout
docs.text:
mkdocs.yml    # The configuration file.
docs/
    index.md  # The documentation homepage.
    ...       # Other markdown pages, images and other files.

docs.title: Creating a MERIT river graph from provided data
docs.text:
Info

This page documentst the create_edges() function

docs.title: Discretization of MERIT flowlines
docs.text:
Given the provided MERIT flowline data, you will notice that there is no standard size/length of these flowlines. Some of the catchments are large (50+ km reaches) others are much smaller (0.5 km reaches).

To get around this, we break up the MERIT river connectivity into smaller pieces based 2 km segments with a 666 m buffer.

This data processing is done with dask/zarr for optimal speed and chunked data storage (fast read/writes).

docs.title: What is being saved to zarr stores
docs.text:
The following data is being saved:

Attribute Description Data Type Example id The edge id str 7402309_1 merit_basin The edge's merit basin int 7402309 segment_sorting_index An ordering index for the edge (Drainage Area) int 2 order Edge stream order int 1 len Edge stream length float 2000.0 len_dir Edge stream Euclidean Length float 2000.0 ds Downstream connection str 7402309_2 up Upstream connection list[str] 7402308_2 up_merit Upstream merit basin list[int] 7402308 slope Edge stream slope float 0.002 sinuosity Edge stream sinuosity float i stream_drop Difference in elevation over the edge length float i uparea Upstream drainage area float 283.29 coords Edge map coordinates str i crs Edge map projection CRS object i

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
The first step to using Marquette is creating a Python environment with all of the required dependencies.

uv support

UV support is still experimental

Anacondauv 
conda create -n marquette python=3.11
conda activate marquette
pip install -r requirements.txt

uv venv
uv pip sync requirements.txt

docs.title: Data
docs.text: The whole purpose of Marquette is to format your hydrofabric data into a format that is usable for \(\delta\)MC river routing. To get the full formatted data, you will need:

docs.text: Data required for MERIT BASINS is available here

docs.title: Running the module
docs.text:
To run the module, prepare a configuration file then run:

python -m marquette

To run over multiple MERIT zones, run using hydra multirun

python -m marquette --multirun zone=71,72,73
